entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 1 at 7:51AM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
Locally dense fog will continue to impact western and northern portions of the Suwannee Valley as well as portions of inland southeast Georgia, generally for locations west of Waycross, through the early morning hours today. Visibilities may be reduced below one half mile at times through around 9 AM.
Slow down where visibility is reduced and allow extra space between vehicles.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 1 at 3:50AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A strong cold front will bring snow squalls, blowing snow, and reduced visibility along with much colder temperatures to the Interior from Fairbanks south to the Alaska Range tonight and Tuesday.
1 to 3 inches of snow is expected from Fairbanks south to the Alaska Range Monday night into Tuesday. Northwest winds gusting over 30 mph will cause low visibility in blowing snow, and snow drifts will form. Temperatures will fall into the single digits tonight and then below zero Tuesday night. Northwest winds and blowing snow will reach Fairbanks, Nenana and Denali this evening and continue into Tuesday morning. The northwest winds and blowing snow will reach Delta Junction, Tok and the Eastern Alaska Range later tonight and early Tuesday morning and continue through the day Tuesday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Upper Tanana Valley; Delta Junction; Upper Chena River Valley; Tanana Flats; Eielson AFB and Salcha; Goldstream Valley and Nenana Hills; Chatanika River Valley; Two Rivers; Fairbanks Metro Area; Nenana; Northern Denali Borough; Southern Denali Borough; Eastern Alaska Range North of Trims Camp; Eastern Alaska Range South of Trims Camp

cap:parameter.value: Strong Cold Front and Snow Squalls Expected Across the Interior Late This Evening and Tuesday

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued April 1 at 3:24AM AKDT until April 1 at 4:00PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 6 to 12 inches.
* WHERE...East Turnagain Arm.
* WHEN...Through 4 PM AKDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. Travel may be difficult. Visibility in heavy snow showers may be reduced to one half mile or less at times.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow showers will continue from Portage to Girdwood through this afternoon. Snowfall rates may reach one to two inches per hour at times in heavier snow showers, reducing visibility to one half mile or less. The highest snowfall accumulations are expected along the Portage Glacier Road and in Girdwood, where 6 to 12 inches of snow could fall. Elsewhere along the Seward Highway, 3 to 6 inches of snow is possible. Snowfall on wet roads may lead to icy conditions this morning as temperatures fall below freezing. Snowfall on area roads may turn slushy by Monday afternoon as temperatures warm back into the mid 30s.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 PM AKDT THIS AFTERNOON

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow showers will continue from Seward to Moose Pass as well as Turnagain Pass and Whittier through Monday afternoon. Snowfall rates may reach one to two inches per hour at times in heavier snow showers, reducing visibility to one half mile or less. The highest snowfall accumulations are expected between Seward and Moose Pass, where 6 to 12 inches of snow could fall. Farther north, 4 to 8 inches of snow is possible from the Y north through Turnagain Pass and Whittier. Snowfall on wet roads may lead to icy conditions this morning as temperatures fall below freezing. entry.title: Flood Watch issued April 1 at 5:09AM EDT until April 2 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Jackson KY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of east central, northeast, and southeast Kentucky, including the following counties, in east central Kentucky, Bath, Elliott, Fleming, Menifee, Montgomery, Powell and Rowan. In northeast Kentucky, Johnson and Martin. In southeast Kentucky, Magoffin, Morgan and Wolfe.
* WHEN...From 8 PM EDT this evening through 8 PM EDT Tuesday evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Several rounds of showers and thunderstorms are expected from this evening through Tuesday evening. Each round of rainfall will have the potential to produce heavy rain, with each successive round having an increasing potential for excessive runoff. Rainfall totals for this event through Tuesday evening will generally range from 1.0 to 2.25 inches, with locally higher amounts possible.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Fleming; Montgomery; Bath; Rowan; Powell; Menifee; Elliott; Morgan; Johnson; Wolfe; Magoffin; Martin

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued April 1 at 4:28AM AST until April 1 at 6:00PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Life-threatening rip currents due to breaking waves between 7-11 feet.
* WHERE...Beaches along the western coastline of Puerto Rico, between Rincon and Aguada. For the high surf, the most vulnerable areas include Barrio Espinal in Aguada.
* WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory, through 6 PM AST this evening. For the High Rip Current Risk, through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents that can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water where it becomes difficult to return to safety. High waves that can wash over jetties and sweep people and pets onto jagged rocks. Rough surf may also knock you down. Minor beach erosion and localized coastal flooding may occur due to high surf.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Rip currents can occur anywhere you have breaking waves, like sandy beaches on the open ocean, but can also occur where there are solid structures,like jetties and piers or even rocks jutting out into the ocean.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 31 at 8:58PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A strong cold front that is bringing blizzard conditions to the West Coast of Alaska on Sunday night will move east across the Southeast Interior Monday night and Tuesday. This front will bring windy conditions along with snow, blowing snow, reduced visibility and much colder temperatures to the Southeast Interior from Fairbanks south to the Alaska Range Monday Night and Tuesday.
Several inches of snow are expected from Fairbanks south to the Alaska Range Monday night into Tuesday. Northwest winds gusting over 30 mph will cause low visibility in blowing snow, and snow drifts will form. Temperatures will fall into the single digits Monday night and remain in the teens on Tuesday. These strong winds and blowing snow will reach Fairbanks, Nenana and Denali Monday evening and continue into Tuesday morning. The strong winds and blowing snow will reach Delta Junction, Tok and the Eastern Alaska Range late Monday night and early Tuesday morning and continue through the day Tuesday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Upper Tanana Valley; Delta Junction; Upper Chena River Valley; Tanana Flats; Eielson AFB and Salcha; Goldstream Valley and Nenana Hills; Chatanika River Valley; Two Rivers; Fairbanks Metro Area; Nenana; Northern Denali Borough; Southern Denali Borough; Eastern Alaska Range North of Trims Camp; Eastern Alaska Range South of Trims Camp

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 31 at 6:12PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary: Widespread snow showers will develop tonight and continue through Tuesday across the Prince William Sound. 6 to 12 inches of snow is possible from Valdez to Cordova with the highest amounts likely in Cordova and through Thompson Pass. Snowfall rates may reach one to two inches per hour at times in heavier snow showers, reducing visibility to one half mile or less. Snowfall on wet roads may lead to icy conditions as overnight temperatures fall below freezing. Snowfall on area roads may turn slushy by Tuesday afternoon as temperatures warm back into the mid 30s.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northeast Prince William Sound; Southeast Prince William Sound

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued March 31 at 11:11AM CDT by NWS Chicago IL
entry.summary:
ESFLOT
Showers and thunderstorms are expected to develop this afternoon and tonight across northern Illinois and northwest Indiana with additional showers and storms expected Monday afternoon through Monday night.
These showers and thunderstorms may produce heavy rainfall rates up to one inch per hour as they move east across northern Illinois and northwestern Indiana. Soil moisture across most of the area ranges from near average to slightly above average, which will have only a limited impact on runoff rates. While most areas will receive rainfall amounts around 1.0 inch, a narrow corridor may receive localized rainfall up to 2.0 to 2.5 inches from multiple rounds of showers and thunderstorms. Rainfall amounts of this magnitude will likely cause rises on area streams and rivers, some of which could reach or exceed flood stage.
This outlook means that elevated water levels and potential impacts are possible, but not yet certain. Persons should closely monitor forecasts including the possibility of flood watches, warnings, and advisories.
No additional outlooks are expected for this event unless the threat for heavy rainfall becomes more certain.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cook, IL; Ford, IL; Grundy, IL; Iroquois, IL; Kankakee, IL; Kendall, IL; La Salle, IL; Livingston, IL; Will, IL; Benton, IN; Jasper, IN; Lake, IN; Newton, IN; Porter, IN

entry.title: Avalanche Advisory issued March 30 at 5:13PM MDT by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
SABCO
THE FOLLOWING MESSAGE IS TRANSMITTED AT THE REQUEST OF THE COLORADO AVALANCHE INFORMATION CENTER.
...SPECIAL AVALANCHE ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 PM MONDAY...
*WHAT...New snow and strong winds are building thick slabs of snow over a recently buried weak layer creating unusually dangerous avalanche conditions.
*WHERE...West Elk and Elk Mountains including the Ruby and Ragged Ranges
*WHEN...Through Monday evening
*IMPACTS...Large, dangerous avalanches are easy to trigger. Avalanches will run naturally above treeline, and some can step down to deeper weak layers resulting in a more destructive avalanche.
*PRECAUTION/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... Avoid avalanche terrain above treeline. In other areas, cautious route-finding and conservative decision-making are essential to travel safely in the backcountry on Sunday and Monday. You can find more detailed information at colorado.gov/avalanche
entry.cap:areaDesc: Gore and Elk Mountains/Central Mountain Valleys; West Elk and Sawatch Mountains
